name: Kepler-206
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-206 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-206 is a star with 1.3639999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.19 times its radius. It is located 1972.62 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-206 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-206 b

Kepler-206 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.78 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-206.

The mass of Kepler-206 b is 1.49 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-206 b is 1.2 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-206 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-206 c

Kepler-206 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.14 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-206.

The mass of Kepler-206 c is 3.79 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-206 c is 1.77 that of Earth. At 3.79 Earth masses, Kepler-206 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-206 d

Kepler-206 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 23.44 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-206.

The mass of Kepler-206 d is 1.46 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-206 d is 1.19 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-206 d is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-206, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
